replies.body: Good. Poaching is bullshit, but lying about breaking rules is, in my opinion, the real offense here. HotShot should have just told the truth, and he would definitely have saved himself and his team a large amount of money. Remember, Bjergsen was only fined $2,000 for poaching because he cooperated with Riot and was honest about it.

Yes, he should have told the truth, but as far as poaching is concerned; it **can **make "players deliberately playing poorly to “force” their organization to release them" but at the same time, it creates an environment where LCS players aren't able to look to their future at all, in an already volatile career

It means that if players want to look for a new team, they aren't allowed to talk to anyone until their contract is already up, which puts them in a situation like Amazing is in: he left hoping to get picked up by a different team, and so far still doesn't have one...had he known he wasn't going to be employed right now, he might not have left TSM, and he would still have a job

I'm not 100% sure on this, but I believe that players are free to approach other teams while still under contract, and I know that teams are able to approach players by going through the organization that currently holds their contract. Yes, this makes it harder for players to get offers from other teams while they're contracted by one specific team, but it is still possible for a player to "explore" options. Scarra could have asked HotShotGG or someone else on CLG whether they were looking for a coach if he really wanted to switch teams. As long as no one on CLG approached Scarra and explicitly offered him a job or asked him to end his contract with Dignitas, it wouldn't have broken any rules, but CLG *did* and they are being punished for it. Rules are rules.

Amazing probably should have done more research before leaving TSM, if that was really his reasoning. He's completely free to ask other teams whether they expect to have open positions at the end of the season, unless that is specifically forbidden by his contract with TSM--which has little to do with Riot.

That's just it, though, Scarra did approach Hotshot.

Hotshot just lied about it because he was scared of the consequences and denied any interaction between them. Now, I'm not saying Scarra walked straight up to Hotshot and told him that he wanted to coach for his team like a female in a dating sim, but what I am saying is that 10,000 is way too steep of a fine for CLG right now, and regardless of how badly George handled the situation, which, yes, he did. This isn't helping the eSports scene, and it's certainly not helping League of Legends. 

For better or for worse, CLG has one of the most hardcore of hardcore-diehard communities out there. I guarantee you that they're going to come out positive through additional donations, and this is especially true if the story ends at Hotshot and Scarra's statements, because I'm going to be honest, it doesn't reflect good on Riot at all.

Source for my blabbering crazy-talk:
http://clgaming.net/news/626-official-statement-re-competitive-ruling-december-10-2014

fully disagree. I feel that this shows how much eSports have advanced. In the beginning I'm sure CLG could have gotten away with that. This set an example for future teams that want to poach other players. I think that what Riot Games did was not only the right thing to do, but also smart. I'm that in the future no team will attempt this without accepting the consequences prior.

I thought about that too, but as far as I understand, the difference in that situation was that Rekkles was the one who approached Alliance - as opposed to Alliance approaching him. At least, that's what I think happened - if I'm wrong, then pls ignore me :)

I believe Alliance approached Fnatic first and could only talk to Rekkles through Fnatic, which made the negotiations last so long because Fnatic wanted to keep Rekkles. But since they approached the organisation first, it's fine.

Alliance bought out Rekkles's contract. It was a fair trade, and both parties agreed upon the transaction made. What CLG did was poaching, what Alliance did was contact the business side of Fnatic, and conducted a business transaction. The price was set by Fnatic, and Alliance agreed on the price.

I'm a CLG fan, but even I can't hate on this decision. I don't see any room for dispute, these penalties are deserved and, if anything, should just promote better business from all LCS participants in the future. The no poaching rule shouldn't apply to substitutes:
1) Riot's statement about how poaching is bad didn't involve any description of how it applied to substitutes.  Riot has not yet made any convincing statement on how being able to approach a substitute would hurt the integrity of the LCS.
2) It gives teams undo control over a player that they themselves are unwilling to evaluate to a starting position, and may chill players desire to fill a substitute role.
3) The community that LCS is designed to entertain and served is not well served by a no poaching rule on substitutes.  If there is a team that can improve their starting line up by acquiring someone not actively playing in the LCS (be it even a substitute) than the entire organization of the LCS is improved by allowing that to happen.
Substitutes are still part of the team therefore still in contract. As long as you are in any team whether its sub or coach or starting lineup, you are still in a contract.
That undermines my point 3, but not 1 and 2.

Because they are still under contract. Hotshot's approach was wrong because they offered the player not the organization. This is clearly stated in the rule.

10.2.12 No Poaching or Tampering.

“No Team Member or Affiliate of a team may solicit, lure, or make an offer of employment to any Team MEMBER who is signed to any LCS team, nor encourage any such Team MEMBER to breach or otherwise terminate a contract with said LCS team. Violations of this rule shall be subject to penalties, at the discretion of LCS officials.”
